title: Missing Words in English
description: Other languages have beautiful words for things English lacks a single word for. Can you match these untranslatable foreign words to their meanings?

questions.question: The German word 'Schadenfreude' describes what feeling that English has no single word for?
The Japanese word 'tsundoku' describes what common habit?
options: Buying books and never reading them

questions.question: The Danish word 'hygge' refers to what concept that has no direct English equivalent?
The Finnish word 'sisu' describes what quality?
The Portuguese word 'saudade' describes what feeling?
options: A deep longing or melancholic nostalgia for something absent

questions.question: The Japanese word 'wabi-sabi' refers to what aesthetic concept?
options: Finding beauty in imperfection and transience

questions.question: The Swedish word 'lagom' means what?
options: Just the right amount, not too much or too little

questions.question: The Italian phrase 'dolce far niente' translates as what?
The German word 'Wanderlust' (borrowed into English) originally meant what?
options: A desire to travel or wander

questions.question: The Georgian word 'shemomedjamo' describes what situation?
options: Continuing to eat even when full because the food is so good

questions.question: The Yiddish word 'chutzpah' (borrowed into English) describes what quality?
The French phrase 'l'esprit de l'escalier' refers to what common experience?
options: Thinking of a perfect reply too late

questions.question: The Inuit word 'iktsuarpok' describes what action?
options: Repeatedly going outside to check if someone is coming

questions.question: The Welsh word 'hiraeth' is similar to 'saudade' and describes what?
options: A deep homesickness or longing for a home that may no longer exist

questions.question: The German word 'Torschlusspanik' literally means 'gate-closing panic' and describes what?
options: The fear that time is running out and opportunities are slipping away
